creator.organizationName: New York City Dept. Environmental Protection

address.deliveryPoint: New York City Dept. Environmental Protection, 71 Smith Ave

abstract.para: This data set is derived from the NY City’s Department of Environmental Protection’s Watershed Protection Program. This involves the monitoring of several reservoirs that provide the drinking water for the City of New York. Nineteen reservoirs provide drinking water to the City, but this data set includes 5 sites in the west Hudson region (except for Rondout Reservoir, which was excluded because it is strongly influenced by water transfers to the system and has a very short residence time) due to restrictions on data usage. In addition to the data set described here, NYCDEP also provided temp/DO profile data. Five reservoirs are included in this data set: Ashokan- east and west basins, Cannonsville, Neversink, Pepacton, and Schoharie. Multiple sites are sampled within each reservoir, and multiple depths are sampled at each site. Often, sampling focuses on epilimnetic and hypolimnetic layers, but often more detailed profiles are included. Temporal sampling: Sampled roughly every two weeks from April or May through November or December of each year. However, not all variables and all depths were sampled on all dates, and in some years, sampling is more intensive.

intellectualRights.para: This information is released to the public under the Creative Commons license CC0 1.0 Universal (https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/) and may be used for academic, educational, or commercial purposes subject to the following restrictions: The Data User must realize that these data sets are being actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the data creators or contacts. Where appropriate, the Data User may be encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators. The Data User must realize that the data may be misinterpreted if taken out of context. The Data User must acknowledge use of the data by an appropriate citation (suggested format includes the DOI). While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is". The creators shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of data sets. Data users should be aware that we periodically update data sets. By using these data, the Data User agrees to abide by the terms of this agreement. Thank you for your cooperation.

section.title: Lab methods
section.para: Samples are analyzed at 3 different certified labs. For the most part, methods changes appear to occur at the same time among the three labs, although there are a few minor discrepancies. However, these are never more than 1 year difference. It is not clear which lab received which samples from which reservoir, however.
Note- “SMXX” refers to the edition # of Standard Methods
Color- apparent color; visual comparison method with matched Nessler tubes,
Values of -1 indicate a sample that was too turbid for color determination
Turbidity- (TURB)
1987-Nephelometric method; Hach Model 2100A turbidimeter; SM16; 214A
1993- Nephelometric method; Hach Model 2100A turbidimeter; SM18; 2130B
1997- Nephelometric method; Hach Model 2100AN turbidimeter; SM18/21; 2130B
Total Phosphorus (TP)-
1987- Persulfate digestion/ascorbic acid method, PE Coleman 44 Spectrophotometer, SM16; 424C-III
1988- Persulfate digestion/ascorbic acid method, PE Coleman 35 Spectrophotometer, SM16; 424C-III
1988- Persulfate digestion/ascorbic acid method, Scientific Instruments autoanalyzer, SM16; 424C-III
1990- Persulfate digestion/ascorbic acid method, Valderrama 1980
1994- Persulfate digestion simultaneous with TN, ascorbic acid, Alpkem Autoanalyzer; Valderrama 1980
1999- Persulfate digestion simultaneous with TN, Alpkem Flow Solution III/IV; Valderrama 1980
2000-Persulfate digestion/ascorbic acid, Alpkem Flow Solution III/IV, SM18; 4500-P, F
2005- Lachat QuickChem 8000, SM18/20; 4500-P, F
2007- Lachat QuickChem 8500; Lachat method 10-115-01-1-F; EPA 365.1. Rev. 2.0
Dissolved Organic Carbon (DOC)-
1987- Dohrman DC-80 Carbon Analyzer, SM18; 5310C
1995- Shimadzu TOC 5000A; SM18; 5310
2002- Shimadzu TOC-VCSH; SM19; 5310
Total Nitrogen (TN)-
1990- Persulfate digestion simultaneous with TP/Cd reduction, Scientific Instruments Autoanalyzer; Valderrama 1980
1994- Persulfate digestion simultaneous with TP/Cd reduction, Alpkem Autoanalyzer; Valderrama 1980
1999- Persulfate digestion simultaneous with TP/Cd reduction, Alpkem Flow Solution III/IV; Valderrama 1980
2002- Furnace combustion/chemoluminescence detection, Shimadzu TOC-VCSH, TOC User Manaul 2001
Chloride (CL)-
1984-1989- AgNO3 buret titration (manual); SM16; 407A
1989- AgNO3 potentiometric titration, Brinkman autotitrator; SM16; 407A
1993-1997 - AgNO3 potentiometric titration, Brinkman autotitrator SM17/18; 4500-Cl, B
2000- Ion chromatography, Dionex DX-300; EPA 1993 300.0
2002- Ion chromatography, Dionex DX-600 with AS4A-SC column; EPA 300.0 or 300.1
2003- Ion chromatography, Lachat, EPA 300.0
2007- Ion chromatography, Dionex ICS 3000, EPA 300.0
2009- same method; range detection listed as 0.5-25.0 mg/L
Sulfate (SO4)-
1987-Turbidimetric Method, PE Coleman 44 spectrophotometer; Limnology Manual
1988- Turbidimetric Method, PE Coleman 35 spectrophotometer; Limnology Manual
1992-Automated methylene blue method, Scientific Instruments autoanalyzer, SM17; 4500-SO4-F
1994- Automated methylene blue method, Alpkem Flow Solution III/IV, SM17/18; 4500-SO4-F
1999- Automated methylene blue method, Alpkem autoanalyzer, SM17/18; 4500-SO4-F
2000- Ion chromatography, Dionex DX-300; EPA 1993, 300.0
2002- Ion chromatography, Dionex DX-600 with AS4A-SC column; EPA 300.0 or 300.1
2003- Ion chromatography, Lachat, EPA 300.0
2007- Ion chromatography, Dionex ICS 3000, EPA 300.0
Chlorophyll a (CHLA)-
1984-1998- Fluorometric method, Turner fluorometer, SM17/18; 10200, H, 3
1998- Hewlitt-Packard 1050 HPLC, SM19; 10200, H5
1998-2004 May- same method, HPLC detector upgraded to HP 1100
Ammonium-N (NH3)-
1988- Nesslerization method, PE Jr. Coleman 35 spectrophotometer, SM16; 417B
1990- Automated phenate method, Scientific Instruments SI 116-D223-02
1992- Automated salicylate method, Scientific Instruments SI 116-D223-02
1994- Automated salicylate method, Alpkem Autoanalyzer, SM18; 4500-NH3, H
1995- Autmoated phenate method, Alpkem Autoanalyzer, SM18; 4500-NH3, H
1999- Automated phenate method, Alpkem Flow Solution III/IV; SM18; 4500-NH3, H

1998- Flow Injection analysis- Lachat QucikChem 8500; Lachat 10-107-06-1-J (Note- different labs switched from Alpkem to Lachat at different times, but unclear which lab analyzed samples from which reservoir).
Nitrate/Nitrite-N (NO3NO2)-
1988- Automated Cd reduction, Scientific Instruments, SM16; 418F
1990- Automated Cd reduction, Scientific Instruments, SM17; 4500NO3-F
1994- Automated Cd reduction, Alpkem Autoanalyzer, SM17/18; 4500-NO3, F
1998 or 1999- Flow Injection Analysis, Lachat QucikChem 8500; Lachat10-107-04-1C
Secchi disc depth (ZSD)- calculated as avg of 2 observations from shady side of boat, by 2 persons and within 19% of each other
pH- (PH)-
1987- SM16; 423 Hydrolab Surveyor II (in situ)
1991-1998 SM17/18; 4500-H+, B Hydrolab Surveyor II (in situ)
1998- Limnology Methods Manual, 7th ed. Begin using temp. corrected values during calibration, Hydrolab Surveyor III (in situ)
2001- Limnology Methods Manual, 7th ed. Hydrolab Surveyor 4a (in situ)
2004- Limnology Methods Manual, 7th ed.; data will come from any of 3 instruments: Hydrolab Surveyor III, Hydrolab Surveyor 4a, or YSI 6600 Datasonde
2009- additional sonde models in the mix- YSI 6920, YSI 600XL
Dissolved oxygen (DO)-
1987- SM16; 421F- Hydrolab Surveyor II (in situ)
1992- SM17; 4500-0, C Hydrolab Surveyor II (in situ)
1994- SM17; 4500-0, C Hydrolab Surveyor III (in situ)
1998- Shokan & Smith 1982 Air saturation H2O calibration procedure; Hydrolab Surveyor III with H2O sonde
2001- Shokan & Smith 1982 Air saturation H2O calibration procedure; Hydrolab Surveyor 4a with H2O sonde
2004- Shokan & Smith 1982 Air saturation H2O calibration procedure; data will come from any of 3 instruments: Hydrolab Surveyor III, Hydrolab Surveyor 4a, or YSI 6600 Datasonde
2009- additional sonde models in the mix- YSI 6920, YSI 600XL
Specific conductance (SPCOND)-
1987- SM16; 205 Hydrolab Surveyor II (in situ)
1991- SM17; 2510B Hydrolab Surveyor II (in situ)
1994-2001- SM17/18; 2510B Hydrolab Surveyor III (in situ)
2001- SM18; 2510B Hydrolab Surveyor 4a (in situ)
2004-SM18; 2510B ; data will come from any of 3 instruments: Hydrolab Surveyor III, Hydrolab Surveyor 4a, or YSI 6600 Datasonde
2009- additional sonde model in the mix- YSI 6920
Alkalinity (ALK)-
1984-1987- Potentiometric titration with a manual buret; SM16; 403
1988-1989- Potentiometric titration with a Brinkman autotritrator; SM16; 403
1990-1995- Potentiometric titration with a Brinkman autotritrator; SM17; 2320B
1996-2000- Potentiometric titration with a Brinkman autotritrator; SM18; 2320B
2001-Automated potentiometric titration; Brinkman autotitrator model 1748; SM18; 2320B
2002- Automated potentiometric titration; Brinkman autotitrator model 751; SM18; 2320B
2008- Automated potentiometric titration; Brinkman autotitrator model 1748; SM18/21; 2320B

description.para: Five reservoirs are included in this data set: Ashokan- east and west basins, Cannonsville, Neversink, Pepacton, and Schoharie. The West-of-Hudson (WOH) NYC Reservoir System is located in the Catskill Mountains and is divided into two separate districts referred to as the Catskill (CAT) and Delaware (DEL) Districts. The Catskill District (CAT) includes Ashokan (EAW and EAE) and Schoharie (SS) Reservoirs while the Delaware District (DEL) includes Cannonsville (WDC), Neversink (NN) and Pepacton (EDP).

samplingDescription.para:
Multiple sites are sampled within each reservoir, and multiple depths are sampled at each site. Often, sampling focuses on epilimnetic and hypolimnetic layers, but often more detailed profiles are included. Reservoirs are sampled roughly every two weeks from April or May through November or December of each year. However, not all variables and all depths were sampled on all dates, and in some years, sampling is more intensive.
Site Locations below: Cannonsville Reservoir (WDC) • Site 1- mid-channel at the Cannonsville Dam • Site 2- mid-channel near Johnny Brook • Site 3- mid-channel up the Trout Creek arm of the reservoir • Site 4- mid-channel across from the intake chamber • Site 5- mid-channel at the widest part of the bay at Chamberlain Brook • Site 6- mid-channel at the influent of the West Branch Delaware River
Neversink Reservoir (NN) • Site 1- mid-channel at the Neversink intake chamber • Site 2- mid-channel between a large peninsula and an unnamed brook near the southern end of the reservoir • Site 3- mid-channel across from the inlet just south of Aden Brook outflow • Site 4- top end of the reservoir in the narrows where the Neversink River enters
Pepacton Reservoir (ED) • Site 1- mid-channel at the Pepacton Dam • Site 2- mid-channel at the influent of Murphy Hill Brook • Site 3- mid-channel across from the intake chamber • Site 4- mid-channel at the influent of Flynn Brook • Site 5- mid-channel at the mouth of the influent of the Tremper Kill • Site 6- mid-channel at the influent of Mill Brook
Ashokan Reservoir- is a two basin system divided by a concrete dividing weir into an east and west basins EAW- sites 1-3 • Site 1-west basin at Olive Dam • Site 2- west basin, influent to reservoir • Site 3- west basin, intake channel at gatehouse
EAE- sties 4-6 • Site 4- intake channel near gatehouse • Site 5- mid-narrows • Site 6- West Hurley and Glenford Dikes
Schoharie Reservoir (SS) • Site 1- at Gilboa Reservoir • Site 2- Halfway between the dam and intake • Site 3- Intake • Site 4- influent to the reservoir

otherEntity.entityDescription: Imports data for the LAke multi-scaled GeOSpatial database (LAGOS)
